awd_titl_txt: CICI: SSC: Securing Science Gateway Cyberinfrastructure with Custos
awd_abstract_narration:
Science gateways are web-based portals for scientists, educators, and students to easily access advanced computing infrastructure, perform reproducible research, and share scientific data. Science gateways are used by tens of thousands of researchers worldwide; thus, gateways are an increasingly attractive target for a wide range of cybersecurity attacks. In cybersecurity terms, science gateways are a collection and integration of a rich set of assets, including user identities, access to a wide range of third party computing and storage resources, sensitive data, licensed or otherwise restricted software, and generated scientific results. The consequences of compromises to science gateways are wide ranging, including unauthorized access to computing resources and data as well as more subtle attacks such as alterations of computed results that may require retraction of publications and otherwise undermine the integrity of the scientific enterprise.  

Through the integration and extension of best-of-breed software, the Custos project provides a single, open source software solution that improves science gateways' management of users identities, secrets such as security tokens used to access a wide range of resources needed for scientific research, and groups and sharing permissions on digital research objects created by science gateway users. Custos software is used to operate a secure, online service with a language-independent programming interface for the science gateway community, providing both an operational platform and a proving ground for research into multi-tenanted, science-focused cyberinfrastructure. The entire Custos environment, including provisioning and operations tools, is openly governed following the meritocracy and diversity principles of the Apache Software Foundation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: The primary goal of this project was to research, develop, and improve science gateway security. The project achieved this goal. 

The project?s principal outcome is the Custos, an innovative integration of the major security capabilities needed by science gateways: identity management, secrets management for third-party resource integration, and group and sharing management for securely controlling permissions and broader access to the digital objects created by a science gateway. 

Intellectual Merit: The Custos system created by this award provides a comprehensive and integrated approach to science gateway security, open source software development, student education based on in-demand technologies, and real-world services operations. The project transformed the security of science gateways by providing these common security capabilities in a single package that is developed and reviewed by both science gateway and cybersecurity experts.  As an open-source project contributed to the Apache Software Foundation, Custos provides a transparent, openly governed code base for managing end-to-end science gateway security scenarios and captures many operational requirements for such systems using an ?infrastructure as code? approach. 

Overall, we published 4 papers about Custos software and integration experiences with Apache Airavata, Galaxy, and Hathi Trust Research Center cyberinfrastructure innovations enabled by this grant. 

Broader Impact: Our project goals were not only to develop security software and publish papers. We operate Custos services on behalf of clients. Science gateways inherently support broader impacts because they are infrastructure to support research and education, and they support more democratic access to computing resources, benefitting underserved groups. Improving the security of science gateways increases trust in the scientific research that gateways enable and increases trust between third-party resource providers and gateway providers.  

One of the challenges facing cyberinfrastructure development is cultivating a talented pipeline of developers. Given that Custos is based on the much larger investments made outside academia into cloud computing infrastructure, it is difficult to hire and retain talented developers within academia. We realized however that we had access to a talented, young, international developer community through our participation in the Apache Software Foundation and our location at Indiana University. We leveraged these connections in several ways. First, we mentored Google Summer of Code projects. Second, we incorporated Custos components into a graduate-level Computer Science course, Applied Distributed Systems, at Indiana University. Over 200 students have taken this course.  The course website is https://courses.airavata.org/, and the course GitHub repository is https://github.com/airavata-courses/.
